Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description:
The Milwaukee Bucks couldn't resist shooting
the open 3, and it often seemed as if they couldn't miss one,
either.
article.headline: Bucks hit 13 3-pointers in victory over Hornets
article.linkText: Bucks' outside shooting dooms host Hornets
article.story:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks couldn't resist shooting the open 3, and it often seemed as if they couldn't miss one, either.
Redd

Milwaukee hit 13 3-pointers Monday night, not to mention a number of shots just inside the arc, in a 108-93 victory over the New Orleans Hornets. "I hope we're not going to live by (the 3-pointer) because you can die by it, but we were just wide open,'' said Michael Redd, who shot 6-of-8 from 3-point range and finished with 22 points. "Tonight every shot was falling for us so it was like, why not? And coach loves when it goes in.'' Sam Cassell led Milwaukee with 25 points and 10 assists, including three 3s. The Bucks shot nearly 53 percent from the field and 50 percent from 3-point range en route to their third straight victory, sixth straight on the road and eighth in nine games overall. David Wesley, who scored 20 points for New Orleans, blamed his team's defense for the Bucks' getting so many open looks. "We weren't moving out there as a unit. We weren't making that second effort,'' Wesley said. "They were finding the gaps in our zone and were knocking down shots.'' Ray Allen scored 22 points and Dan Gadzuric added 10, including a pair of dunks. Tony Kukoc hit a pair of 3-pointers and finished with 10 points. "We're a good shooting team. We were passing the ball well,'' Bucks coach George Karl said. "In the NBA, the pass influences the game. We had a lot of good shots in transition.'' Jamal Mashburn led New Orleans with 24 points, while Robert Pack, starting for the injured Baron Davis, scored a season-high 15. Karl said the Hornets "didn't have their strut'' without Davis in the lineup, but Wesley said New Orleans couldn't use that as an excuse when Milwaukee enjoyed a 47-34 rebounding advantage and had so many open shots. "Baron can't make us rebound. Baron can't make us defend. And tonight, that's what beat us,'' Wesley said. Hornets coach Paul Silas said the Bucks' shooting might have been too good to overcome anyway. "They were coming down the court in transition and letting it fly. When they do that, there's not too much you can do,'' Silas said. Milwaukee blew the game open in the third quarter with a bevy of 3-pointers, complemented by pair of fast-break baskets off Hornets turnovers. Redd and Allen hit back-to-back 3s to cap a 12-0 run and give the Bucks a 73-53 lead. After the Hornets scored four quick points, Milwaukee came back with a 10-0 run, including 3s by Redd and Kukoc, to push the Bucks' lead to 83-57. New Orleans came back with a 9-0 run that included one of Wesley's three 3-pointers, but Kukoc responded with his second 3 to give the Bucks an 86-66 lead heading into the fourth quarter. New Orleans made one last attempt to come back. Pack's driving layup as he got fouled and the ensuing free throw brought the Hornets to 95-85 with 5:34 left. But Milwaukee rattled off six quick points, including two open inside baskets by Ervin Johnson, and New Orleans never got close again. Early on, Cassell found Gadzuric for an alley-oop dunk to finish a 13-2 run and give Milwaukee a 26-14 lead. But Wesley hit a right wing jumper off a fast break to spark an 8-0 New Orleans run. The Hornets took a brief 33-32 lead when Wesley hit his first 3-pointer, but Redd responded with his third 3-pointer of the half and Milwaukee quickly rebuilt its lead. The Bucks hit six 3-pointers in the first half, four by Redd and one each by Cassell and Allen. New Orleans struggled shooting at times, but stayed in the game with nine steals in the first half -- including one by Pack that he turned into an end-to-end layup to pull New Orleans to 49-48. Redd's fourth 3 of the half put the Bucks up 54-48 and Milwaukee carried a 56-50 lead into halftime. Game notes
With the Hornets signing free-agent Randy Livingston on Monday and with Johnson in town with the Bucks, three New Orleans natives saw action in their hometown. Pack is in his second 10-day contract. ... Davis is out three-to-six weeks with an injured left knee. ... Johnson lost his bearings on an open dunk attempt, stuffing himself on the front rim. ... Johnson, a former star at the University of New Orleans, and Livingston, who played at LSU, said they each had dozens of ticket requests. "It got to the point I had to take my phone off the hook,'' said Livingston, who had been playing in the CBA in Sioux Falls before the Hornets signed him to a 10-day contract. ... Milwaukee scored the most points by a visiting team at New Orleans Arena this season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
